matingTips.description: From preparation to the perfect timing – a step-by-step guide for successful breeding

healthRequirements.title: Health requirements & breed-specific testing
healthRequirements.content: Before mating, make sure both dogs fulfill the health requirements for your breed.
items: Check what health tests are required or recommended by your national kennel club or breed club (e.g. hip x-ray, eye exams, DNA tests)
Ensure the dogs are healthy, of appropriate age, and in good condition
Vaccinations should be up to date
Avoid mating dogs with known heritable health problems

reviewPedigrees.title: Review pedigrees & plan the match
reviewPedigrees.content: Choose a combination that supports your breed's goals and long-term health.
items: Inbreeding coefficient (COI)
Temperament, type and structure
Known health history
reviewPedigrees.tip: Consult your breed club or a mentor if you're unsure.

waitForHeat.title: Wait for standing heat
waitForHeat.content: The female is ready to mate when she enters standing heat. Look for:
items: A soft, swollen vulva
Lighter-colored discharge (straw or pale pink)
She stands still and moves her tail to the side when approached by the male
waitForHeat.tip: This often occurs around day 10–14 of the heat cycle – but it varies!

progesteroneTesting.title: Use progesterone testing
progesteroneTesting.content: A progesterone test at the vet can help pinpoint ovulation and find the best day to mate.
items: Timing natural matings more precisely
Planning travel or artificial insemination
Bitches with irregular heat cycles

twoMatings.title: Consider two matings
twoMatings.content: Two matings 24–48 hours apart often increase the chance of pregnancy.
items: Sperm can live for several days
Helps ensure that mating overlaps with ovulation

calmEnvironment.title: Keep the environment calm
calmEnvironment.content: Stress can disrupt the mating process.
items: Use a calm, familiar setting
Let the dogs meet beforehand if possible
Keep people and distractions to a minimum

bonusTips.title: Bonus Tips for a Planned Litter
items: Track heat cycles regularly (use a journal or app)
Book your vet in advance if using testing or insemination
Prepare stud dog's documents in advance (pedigree, health records)
Read the relevant breeding rules from your kennel club
